content.content: It was brought to GovAlpha’s attention earlier today that the wording of a Governance Poll posted yesterday was potentially misleading. The Governance Poll in question asked MKR holders whether or not they approved a proposal from the Strategic Finance CU for a tactical re-allocation of budgets. The initial copy could have been misunderstood to suggest that any changes as a result of this process could have entered directly to an Executive Vote, which was not the case. This has now been clarified in the poll copy by this Pull Request. The Outcomes section of the vote now appears as follows on the voting portal:  image921×289 17 KB  We felt this means of clarification appropriate as not much MKR had voted so far, and stopping the poll and delaying it until next week seemed counter-productive in this instance. GovAlpha apologises for any inconvenience or confusion that this may have caused. Please get in touch with us if you have any questions. I have reached out to the Recognized Delegates who already voted on this poll. cc: @strat-fin-core-unit @GovAlpha-Core-Unit @Recognized-Delegates

Could you please also revise the first bullet of the poll outcome? This Signal is to determine if the DAO wants to move forward with a tactical reallocation of the budgets and does not necessarily require SFs involvement to coordinate.
Who is going to facilitate this process if not SF? We thought that was implied as your CU originated the proposal.

What are we voting on with this? So, a poll where 54% of people abstain can still get implemented by governance? The reasons for some abstentions (certainly mine) was a fundamental disagreement with the whole approach, therefore choosing among the available options did not align with a desired outcome.

As with any Signal Request, votes for “abstain” do not count and a majority of “non-abstain” votes can move a Signal on-chain. If you disagree with the proposed approach, you should vote “No” on the on-chain poll.

Okay - but I felt abstain was a better way to communicate my views that the proposal was not well placed for consideration by the community at all. So, I don’t think the NO option was correct for my particular views on the matter.

Delegates are particularly well positioned to assist in facilitating the process, but the purpose of the signal was not to designate anyone to facilitate said process, but to determine if the DAO supported it or a broad cut approach.

This signals that voting YES on this proposal is also a vote in support of treating Recognized Delegates as a “management council” that would be above and beyond the current expectations of an RD. I will be voting against, primarily for this reason.

Delegates are definitely not particularly well positioned to assist. The proposal requires very specific set of expertise to administer, not to mention that the current Recognized Delegate role is explicitly NOT a management or operational role. If this proposal does not include a facilitator and is not specific on the HOW and by whom the proposal will be implement, I do not think it is proper to put forward for an onchain vote.

This proposal at it’s core is about Accountability, Transparency, and confirming how the DAO would like to proceed in returning to cash flow breakeven, which in my view is a pre-requisite for burning MKR. Delegates and MKR holders address the principal-agent problem by being in a position within the DAO to hold CUs accountable. This is already happening, except without any structure or transparency, as delegate conversations and performance assessment discussions are currently being held behind doors, if at all. With that said, SF is happy to work with the community and all stakeholders to bootstrap, facilitate, and assist in the process and further iterate the framework if the community decides a tactical reallocation is in the DAO’s best interest.

Aes:  if at all.   It is not happening. Accountability is not happening because no one has the mandate or incentive to take on that role and responsibility. I do applaud and see what SF is trying to achieve, but it has not been solved for or decided how the principal-agent problem at MakerDAO is going to get fixed.

I’d like to point out two things: First, watching the presentation that SFCU gave in the DVC, I came away with the impression that SF would serve CUs in setting reasonable, actionable, simple, and attainable high-level KPIs that would help the DAO evaluate performance and guide budget allocations. We agreed that the devil is in the details, and @monkey.irish pointed out that KPIs can be a major productivity drain and we have to be very cautious in implementing these, while @pipko pointed out that the first generation of KPIs we develop is unlikely to be the silver bullet we look for. And second, I find the proposal gives too much discretion to both SF and delegates, mainly in an off-chain process to arrive at KPIs. I’d love to see something much simpler and more decentralized. CUs take the KPIs they already have, SF helps them tie that to overarching DAO goals like break-even profitability, and CUs publish these KPIs with their budget proposals. Delegates can then individually vote on that. I know this is not the kind of “efficient decision making” which we all probably know from traditional orgs, but this is not such an organization. We need to make very sure we do not create the impression of centralized control. I also do not want to have power concentrated in advisory CUs or delegate councils. Delegates can and do talk amongst each other, and this helps to expedite decision-making. I think CUs already have high-level, measurable goals they strive to attain. SF should work with CUs on a one-on-one basis to gather these metrics, help CUs understand how budget constraints can affect them, and then help them present these to voters during budget proposals. SF could be a kind of information hub and DAO accounting powerhouse.

rspa:  First, watching the presentation that SFCU gave in the DVC, I came away with the impression that SF would serve CUs in setting reasonable, actionable, simple, and attainable high-level KPIs that would help the DAO evaluate performance and guide budget allocations.   I think anybody from this DAO should be able to participate and make recommendations, and in fact help develop Key Performance Questions, before KPIs are set in stone. What do I mean by Key Performance Questions? Well, as an example (humor me for a second) someone in the working group can ask the Question:  How many new devs does the DAO need to onboard by Q4 2022, and why does it need new devs onboarded by Q4 2022?  Which in turn is measured by a KPI such as, “Devs to be hire in 2022” and why devs need to be hire by Q4 2022. The DAO needs to figure out what Questions it needs to have an Answer to in order to understand how well a CU is performing and executing a strategy. Sometimes in life it’s better to ask a Question than to have all the answers. I believe it was Google who once said that they run their operations by asking Questions, rather than having answers. Hence, I don’t believe this Poll is asking any of the participants to centralize KPIs. A good example of how KPQs can be designed via a Decentralized interactive workshop working group, is what @0xdeniz & @Davidutro did with a Figma Tool:  image1538×884 84.8 KB  This  workshop ask Questions first, and then it tried to define what Performance thinking related steps need to be taken in order to measure good performance. Once the working group composed of many participants has identified the questions that need to be answered–then evaluating all existing data will lead to the right KPIs. And yes it sounds easy, and its not. But as I always believe, we won’t know until we try.     rspa:  I also do not want to have power concentrated in advisory CUs or delegate councils. Delegates can and do talk amongst each other, and this helps to expedite decision-making.   The problem with not having delegates involved is that when it comes to voting on KPI parameters most won’t understand what Strategy, Questions, and Answers were used to define a certain CU KPI. Therefore, each Delegate Platform will be guessing based on their own unique belief–versus putting in the work and getting their hands dirty, aka, participating in a working group. Believe me when I tell you that since inception, I and other Delegates have played a guessing game, or an opinionated game, because we had no idea what Strategy, Questions, and Answers were being asked.     rspa:  I think CUs already have high-level, measurable goals they strive to attain.   While I agree with you that most CUs have goals that they aspire to attain, the problem is MKR token owners won’t know and won’t understand what those goals are without identifiable KPIs. Unfortunately that’s just human nature. Show me the money.

flipflopflapdelegate:  help develop Key Performance Questions, before KPIs are set in stone.   This is great! That is exactly the kind of dialogue I can get behind. And very different than a council of delegates sitting down with SF CU to formulate KPIs that CUs then have to hit First and foremost, we need this dialogue because it brings the debate around budgets from: “Uh bloat bad, fire everyone!”, to a rational place of inquiry and mutual understanding.     flipflopflapdelegate:  A good example of how KPQs can be designed via a Decentralized interactive workshop working group is what @0xdeniz & @Davidutro did with a Figma Tool:   Great procedure, I wasn’t aware of. To tie it back to what to do: My exercise of somehow defining a framework for surfacing DAO priorities is very close in spirit to your push for KPQs. In both cases, the process of inquiry is what’s central, and the value is something emergent. I highly encourage any efforts in that direction, but I don’t see how the proposal discussed here is lending itself to that. If you see a way there, please show me where.

rspa:  And very different than a council of delegates sitting down with SF CU to formulate KPIs that CUs then have to hit   From the start it is said that it is not SF but each facilitator that will pick his own KPIs.
Thanks for the clarification, that eases some of my concerns.

Please explain to me in more detail how you want this process to work. It seems you put some thought into this. How do delegates and CU’s arrive at KPIs, and what specifically is SF CU’s role there? Obviously, I’m not clear how this is supposed to work, and the current proposal has massive potential for centralization, in my opinion. Maybe you can shed a light on the proceedings and put my mind at ease.

Let me ping @Aes , @pipko and @adcv . I’m not at all involved in this project (nor in anything related to CU expenses in general). I can tell you how I see it as a community member. If I was a CU my main KPI would be to onboard 500M of short-term bonds end of year. There is plenty of reasons why I shouldn’t succeed. Let’s say it ends up at 0M. Well that would be a good time to analyze why I didn’t. Because I didn’t worked, wasn’t pushy enough, bad luck? Doesn’t need you punish the CU directly but at least you have a discussion and try to improve what can be improved. If I have such an 500M target and no one complained, it should at least avoid that, down the line, delegates are all having concerns, those KPI could be bring up. The KPIs would go both ways to me. A tool for discourse. Key point, being a tool. Community already spent too much time overthinking that.

SebVentures:  The KPIs would go both ways to me. A tool for discourse.   I like that a lot, but that’s not what I see in the proposal. That’s what I heard in the presentation in the DVC and what I think is necessary. Have some more objective way to discuss what is currently a mushy, emotional debate. But the current proposal is too broad and too unprecise to deliver, while opening up avenues to centralization and power concentrations, as both Schuppi and Chris Blec pointed out.

rspa:  How do delegates and CU’s arrive at KPIs, and what specifically is SF CU’s role there?   The initial KPIs will be submitted as part of the budget proposals that each CU submits on the forums. As with budget requests today, we assume there will be some dialogue on the forum with MKR holders and delegates and the CUs will likely tweak or update their KPIs based on that dialogue. CUs are free to develop their KPIs on their own before presenting to the community or can ask SFCU for assistance. SFCU’s role will be to collect and aggregate the initial and updated budget and KPI information from the forums and present this information back to MKR holders to inform their competing capital allocation plans.

rspa:  This is great! That is exactly the kind of dialogue I can get behind. And very different than a council of delegates sitting down with SF CU to formulate KPIs that CUs then have to hit   Could you point out where the SFCU proposal discusses “council of delegates” or “sitting down with the SFCU to formulate KPIs”?
This concern has been addressed by @SebVentures, I’m more comfortable with that part now.     rspa:  Thanks for the clarification, that eases some of my concerns.

rspa:  First and foremost, we need this dialogue because it brings the debate around budgets from: “Uh bloat bad, fire everyone!”, to a rational place of inquiry and mutual understanding.   Heavy plus one. It seems like this proposal is rife with misunderstandings when it’s supposed to be a dialogue.     pipko:  Could you point out where the SFCU proposal discusses “council of delegates” or “sitting down with the SFCU to formulate KPIs”?   ctrl-f for council and it has one result. Seems like the “public calls with MKR holders” got interpreted as public calls with management?  If delegates are to serve any role here, it would be to help ask better questions, which enables KPI performance; to @flipflopflapdelegate 's point. Happy to help facilitate aggregation meetings and the like (put those Figma skills to work). My hunch continues to be that KPI’s might be the wrong lens, I think aggregation at a project level into general strategic direction, by when, and measured “by how”  is more fruitful. But the SF team is serving in that function, and this should be a useful exercise.

twblack88:  My hunch continues to be that KPI’s might be the wrong lens, I think aggregation at a project level into general strategic direction, by when, and measured “by how” is more fruitful.   I fully support that, and it ties in nicely with @flipflopflapdelegate’s KPQs. We need a framework for that. Seeing the dialogue here, I feel I probably overshot my mark and misinterpreted the intention of SF CU. But the proposal left so much open to imagination, and this means to exploitation. Let’s keep this dialogue open and come to something more finely attuned to the needs of all involved while safeguarding decentralization completely.

To continue the dialogue here (which is great), @flipflopflapdelegate do you have an example initiative (i.e. RWAs, PSM, etc.) with KPQs and the corresponding KPIs that they produce? Feel free to make one up, but it’s helpful to see what you are envisioning. If we are thinking of the same questions and KPIs, your process is basically the same process we hope the community (MKR holders and delegates) would apply to each CU’s budget proposal during the proposal process.     rspa:  But the proposal left so much open to imagination, and this means to exploitation.   This signal was to determine if the DAO a tactical cut or a broad cut approach at a high level. If helpful, we could draft an explicit step by step process which would take longer. FWIW, dialogue like this helps immensely in developing the process.

pipko:  If helpful, we could draft an explicit step by step process which would take longer.   Personally, this would help me a lot. First, because to get there we would already need to continue this dialogue and come to some sort of fruition. Second, we would limit scope meaningfully. Limited scope means limited power, means increased decentralization.

Bottom up KPIs help for discovering how each team sees their role and their individual objectives. It does not address top down strategic alignment. Investing the effort now to engage in setting KPIs could be seen as premature absent an organizing frame to tie the two together. KPIs ideally work up to achieve the strategic objectives. If we do want a DAOwide global performance evaluation framework perhaps an MIP set is the best format. Much like the recent delegate MIP set, there could be a prolonged RFC term where the various stakeholders work together. If this is done in parallel to the DVCs, then the implementation would follow a logical chronological order. A basic first step could be to ask for KPIs in any budget adjustments or renewal. This seems painless low hanging fruit that could get us moving in the right direction?

pipko:  do you have an example initiative   The following is a quick & dirty example and does not constitute Financial Advice  Define RWF CU Strategic Goal Strategy: RWA onboarding via Arrangers What is the Purpose: to onboard Arrangers that will scale DAI supply and incur a revenue stream that is beneficial to the DAO. What is the ambition: Scale DAI supply by 3B in the next 12-months. Target Market: RWA Portfolio Managers that have at least 5-years experience and that provide first loss-capital and assures MakerDAO as Senior Secured. Value Proposition: What does DAI offer it’s customers/end-users? Innovation, quality, relationship, and lower funding rates. Core Competencies: Decentralized lending platform that allows Arrangers to develop and produce a unique product (DAI) offering to the Real World. Finance Objectives: produce Stability Fees of 120M DAI per annum. The Surplus Buffer incurs 120M DAI minus RWF CU expenses then the DAO makes a profit of ______. Competition and Risk: What is market competition doing that MakerDAO does not do well, and what are the operations and financial risks to the DAO. Audience: RWF CU mandated actor, SF CU, Working Group, etc. once you have an “audience” what Questions do ALL participants have?  Key Performance Questions  To what extend is the RWF CU, or can the RWF CU help deliver bottom line results? How and can the DAO attract qualified RWA Portfolio managers over the next 12-months? What is the time horizon to onboard an Arranger, and is it possible to speed up the process? How can the DAO communicate to the world that DAI is an innovative tool for onboarding RWAs? To what extend can MakerDAO offer lower rates than its competition, and how will MakerDAO outperform other Platforms vying for RWA collateral Types? How will this indicator be used? Will it be used to measure success of the CU or just to measure growth of this type of asset class?   Name & Assign the Indicator  Gather available & supporting metrics or data that you need in order to answer the questions above. Make sure the data collection is completely aligned with the  strategy and it can help fully answer the questions above. Every KPI needs a name so that the participants can discuss it collectively.  Indictors are not targets. The DAO should use benchmarks. Example: in Q3 2022 500M of RWAs will be onboarded. In Q4 of 2002, the benchmark will be 1.2B, etc. (define thresholds) Collect KPI date on a monthly basis, therefore MKR owners can track trends via the SES KPI Dashboard Assigned responsible key stakeholders that will monitor & feed the data into the SES KPI dashboard (hopefully this can be automated) Assign an expiry/revision date for indicators. Seasons change, people change. Assess 12-months later if the indicator is worth using.
This topic was automatically closed 90 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
